newsitem.title: FRANCE: Renault head sees bigger losses - paper. [CORRECTED 08:44 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Renault head sees bigger losses - paper. [CORRECTED 08:44 GMT]

text.p: The chairman of French carmaker Renault told a French newspaper on Monday he expects the trend in losses seen in 1996 to deepen.
(Corrects name of company from PSA Peugeot Citreon to Renault, throughout.)

Asked in an interview in La Tribune about the trend of losses mentioned at the announcement of first-half results, Louis Schweitzer said, "In a difficult economic context and taking into account the price wars and discounts tougher than expected in France, I can only unfortunately announce a strengthening of the trend."
Schweitzer said he expected the environment in 1997 "will be much more difficult than in 1996."
He reaffirmed a forecast that the European market would be in slight retreat and that estimated French sales would fall to 1.9 million cars from 2.1 million.
"I do not think the price war will stop," he added. "We are in a new situation where the price of cars in Europe is falling in constant francs and certainly in current francs."
However, Renault had two positive elements. It had cut costs and launched the Megane range and the Scenic utility vehicle. -- Paris newsroom +33 1 4221 5452 pnt
